channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Luxury villa where new Madeleine McCann suspect Christian Brueckner raped a 72-year-old US tourist
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Christian Brueckner broke into the secluded home two years before the three-year-old went missing from her family's apartment in the resort of Praia da Luz.

item.title: George Floyd's girlfriend says they planned to open restaurant
item.description: Courteney Ross, 44, was pictured in a somber moment on Thursday as she placed her hand on George Floyd's casket during the service at a sanctuary at North Central University in Minneapolis.

item.title: Fortress White House: Tall black fences go up around 1600 Pennsylvania Ave as protests continue
item.description: Tall, black fences have sprung up around the perimeter of the White House as protesters have demonstrated over the death of George Floyd.

item.title: Madeleine McCann: Met sources blast Portuguese police
item.description: Police in Portugal came under fire tonight for their lacklustre response to the biggest potential breakthrough in the abduction of Madeleine McCann since she first disappeared 13 years ago.

item.title: Ruth Davidson reveals 'keeping her head above water' becomes 'harder' the longer lockdown goes on
item.description: Ruth Davidson, 40, who lives in Edinburgh, revealed her mental health struggles during lockdown as she admitted it was becoming 'harder' to keep her 'head above water' throughout lockdown.

item.title: Police link Madeleine McCann suspect to disappearance of schoolboy, 6
item.description: BREAKING: German detectives investigating Christian B, 43, have contacted the family of René Hasee to say they were looking into his 1996 abduction again.

item.title: Coronavirus England: Infection figures may be triple ONS data
item.description: Public Health England and Cambridge University estimate that 16,700 people are catching Covid-19 each day, while the Office for National Statistics puts the figure at 5,570 in the community.

item.title: Maddie McCann suspect sold his VW campervan in 2015 to a car scrapyard
item.description: Madeleine McCann prime suspect Christian Breuckner, 43, sold the Volkswagen van for £5,000 in 2015 to a German compatriot who ran an unofficial yard in the Silves area of the Algarve.

item.title: Matt Hancock warns protesters against going to George Floyd demonstrations amid Covid-19 pandemic
item.description: Health Secretary Matt Hancock tonight warned Britons not to attend large scale anti-racism demonstrations this weekend due to the risk of coronavirus, which he said remained a 'real threat'.

item.title: BBC Studios chief Tim Davie will replace Tony Hall as director-general
item.description: Mr Davie said: 'Our mission has never been more relevant, important or necessary. I have a deep commitment to content of the highest quality and impartiality.'

item.title: Government advisers warned that PHE's contact tracing capacity would be 'exhausted' in TWO WEEKS
item.description: Papers submitted to the Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies (SAGE) reveal the evidence government officials were receiving in March and April as the coronavirus gripped the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Fears NW and SW England to stay in lockdown
item.description: Separate estimates produced by experts at Public Health England and Cambridge University today suggested the R rate is above the danger level in both these parts of England.

item.title: Mystery caller who spoke to German paedophile minutes before Madeleine McCann was abducted is named
item.description: Police are working to locate and interview Diogo Silva to see what he might know about Christian Brueckener's movements on the night Madeleine went missing.

item.title: GCSE and A-Level pupils face being given WRONG grades
item.description: Pupils risk being handed the wrong GCSE and A-Level grades after concerns were raised over the system used to input results following the cancellation of summer exams due to coronavirus.

item.title: Care home manager jailed after stealing money from residents
item.description: Helen Hughes, 56, took money from five residents of the Ashton Park Care Home in Newport, South Wales to give to her online lover who conned her into thinking he was an American soldier.

item.title: Asteroid travelling at 11,000mph will zip past Earth at a distance of 3.1 million miles tonight
item.description: Despite being nearly 3.1 million miles away - 12 times further out than the Moon - the asteroid is classed as a near Earth object by astronomers and is tracked by NASA.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Does evidence show virus IS getting weaker?
item.description: An average of 114,000 people were diagnosed with coronavirus worldwide in the last seven days, up from 86,000 per day at the start of May - but deaths in the same time frame fell from 5,100 to 4,300.

item.title: British captive Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe's husband warns time is running out
item.description: British-Iranian Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe's husband Richard has blasted the UK Government for not doing more to get her out of a 'hostage situation' in Iran.

item.title: Rowing coach jailed for six years after posing as 16-year-old girl to get 32 teenage boys to undress
item.description: Andrew Cook was convicted of 37 sexual offences involving boys aged between 13 and 17 at London's Hampton School. The teacher posed as a teenage girl, under the name of Anne Jones.

item.title: Keighley postwoman SHOT in the face with airgun while on duty
item.description: The postwoman was blasted by a sniper with a powerful airgun while making deliveries to Spring Bank Rise in Keighley, West Yorkshire, was rushed to hospital with facial injuries.

item.title: Reddit's Alexis Ohanian RESIGNS to help 'curb racial hate'
item.description: Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian made the shock announcement in a video uploaded to his Instagram page Friday midday.

item.title: Sen Tom Cotton blasts NYT as it caves in over op-ed calling for troops to quash protests
item.description: Sen Tom Cotton of Arkansas questioned backpedaling at the New York Times after it claimed his op-ed was rushed into the editorial process and did not meet the newspaper's standards.

item.title: How Boris Johnson's approach to tackling the coronavirus crisis has been hit by blunders and rows
item.description: Boris Johnson is facing growing questions over the UK's response to the coronavirus pandemic with Britain's official death toll now approaching 40,000.

item.title: Did UK's coronavirus crisis peak BEFORE lockdown?
item.description: Modelling by Professor Simon Wood, a mathematician at the University of Bristol, shows the spread of the virus had already peaked several days before the draconian curbs were imposed.

item.title: Bill Murray's son arrested during Black Lives Matter protest
item.description: Caleb Murray, the son of legendary actor Bill Murray was arrested on Monday in Vineyard Haven Massachusetts during a Black Lives Matter protest.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Face masks compulsory in hospitals from 15 June
item.description: Medical and other staff will have to wear surgical masks at all times, while outpatients and visitors will not be allowed in without wearing the sort of face coverings that can be made at home.

item.title: It's harder to learn about science with modern technology, astrophysicist claims
item.description: Lord Martin Rees, Astronomer Royal, said it was difficult to take a smartphone apart in the same way as dismantling a clock or an engine was in the past.

item.title: Donald Trump calls massive fall in unemployment a 'great day' for cop victim George Floyd
item.description: President Donald Trump said at the White House Friday that said murdered George Floyd was 'looking down' at the country and it was a 'great day' for him following an unexpectedly strong jobs report.

item.title: The wacky new Tony's Chocolonely mega chocolate factory that has a ROLLER COASTER running through it
item.description: Tony's Chocolonely has released a rendering for its new factory in the Netherlands, which it says will be a 'total experience where you can learn everything about chocolate'.

item.title: German accused of snatching Maddie McCann molested a six-year-old girl
item.description: Christian Brueckner was 17 in 1994 when he attacked the little girl in his home town of Wurzburg, Bavaria - and he only stopped groping her when she started screaming and crying.

item.title: Troops storm beaches, scale cliffs and swoop over occupied France in stunning unseen photos
item.description: Photos colourised by an Artificial Intelligence algorithm show British and US troops storming the beaches and talking to members of the French Resistance after the D-Day landings in Normandy.

item.title: Polymer coating for plants could be safer alternative to pesticides
item.description: A new polymer coating developed at the University of Nottingham could serve as a safer alternative to pesticides in controlling harmful fungi that devastates plant crops.

item.title: Father-of-five battered fiancee after she invited her mother to join them on holiday
item.description: Patrick Heaney, from Ardwick, Manchester,, was hoping for an intimate break to Wales with bride-to-be Chloe Pallagi - but was enraged when her mother and other relatives agreed to tag along.

item.title: BAME staff account for 60 per cent of Covid-19 health worker deaths
item.description: One hundred out of the 166 UK NHS heroes looked at were from BAME backgrounds, while 39 (23 per cent) were white and 27 (16 per cent) were of unknown ethnicity.
item.media:description: BAME healthcare staff who have died during the Covid-19 pandemic (PA)

item.title: Coronavirus UK: 357 new deaths amid worries of R rate rise
item.description: Department of Health bosses have yet to reveal the breakdown of where the deaths occurred - but NHS England recorded 123 more deaths in patients who tested positive in hospitals.

item.title: Third of dentists plan to reopen next week with most to welcome patients again by end of June
item.description: The government said practices could open their doors in England from Monday but some will not due to a lack of PPE. Pictured: An emergency practice in London last week.

item.title: Madeleine McCann suspect investigated over German abduction
item.description: Prosecutors have re-opened the investigation into whether Christian Brueckner abducted Inga Gehricke after she vanished in Saxony-Anhalt during a family outing in 2015.

item.title: World's biggest super-yacht worth £515 million arrives in UK after a week-long voyage from Barcelona
item.description: Dilbar arrived this morning and proved to be a spectacular sight as she made her way up Southampton Water, drawing plenty of admiring glances as she cruised past Hythe.

item.title: Hydroxychloroquine does NOT treat coronavirus, biggest study into the drug finds
item.description: Oxford University scientists pulled the drug from the Recovery trial today after results showed hydroxychloroquine had no benefit on NHS patients hospitalised with the virus.

item.title: Police order evidence review against man suspected of spitting on rail worker who died of Covid-19
item.description: Belly Mujinga died in April aged 47 of coronavirus, a few weeks after the incident at London's Victoria Station. In a new statement, police have invited the CPS to conduct an independent review.

item.title: Single mum admits she 'puts herself' before her son, 10, in Britain's Best Parent
item.description: Single mum Hannah, from Buckinghamshire, was branded 'lazy' by viewers after admitting she puts herself before her son Jack, 10, in last night's episode of Channel 4's Britain's Best Parent.

item.title: Joe Biden says 10 to 15 per cent of Americans 'are not good people' during online discussion
item.description: Former Vice President Joe Biden told supporters online Thursday 'there are probably anywhere from 10 to 15 percent of the people out there that are just not very good people.'

item.title: Lancet paper warning against hydroxychloroquine retracted
item.description: The paper's claim that hydroxychloroquine increases the risk of death in Covid-19 patients has been used by rivals as a stick to beat the US President, who has himself been taking the drug.

item.title: Father-to-be, 27, who was wrongly accused of being a paedophile
item.description: Scott Brown, 27, and his fiancée Tara Cuff, had returned home to Blaenau Gwent, after a shopping trip to discover he'd been wrongly identified by the Facebook group, UK Database.

item.title: Adventure travel writer Sadie Whitelocks ventures inside a remote nomadic Mongolian tribe camp
item.description: During an off-roading adventure through Mongolia, Sadie Whitelocks stopped off for tea with a welcoming local family. She was shown how they milk a horse and served snuff in their ger.

item.title: Scientist explains all the dangerous mysteries of space
item.description: How to Die in Space: A Journey Through Dangerous Astrophysical Phenomena, by astrophysicists Paul M. Sutter, says that space is a 'nasty' place that should be avoided.

item.title: Princess Martha Louise says dating black man has given her 'crash course in white supremacy'
item.description: The princess, 48, said that before she began dating self-described shaman Durek Verrett, 45, in May 2019, she did not realise how widespread racism is.

item.title: London's secret Covid raves: How organisers are using WhatsApp and Instagram to run illegal parties
item.description: Organisers charged £15-a-head for the gatherings in Leytonstone, east London, which saw clubbers dance to house music in close proximity.

item.title: Travellers take over picturesque market town as council bid to evict them is delayed by coronavirus
item.description: A traveller encampment has taken over the picturesque town of Bakewell leaving residents furious. Local council are yet unable to take action, until the full lifting of coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: St Andrews University comes under fire about the lack of diversity
item.description: The University of St Andrews has come under fire over its lack of diversity and treatment of students of colour against the backdrop of the ongoing Black Lives Matter protests.

item.title: Soldier killed in action lied about age to join D-Day landings
item.description: Jack Banks, from Darwen, Lancashire, who lied about his age to enlist in the British Army, was among the first wave of soldiers to land on Gold Beach as part of Operation Overlord in June 1944.

item.title: Vintage motorbike Colonel Tom Moore used to race on in the 1950s is uncovered at museum
item.description: The timeworn Scott Flying Squirrel is on display at Bradford Industrial Museum in West Yorkshire, but its history wasn't known until a stash of black and white photos were recently discovered.

item.title: Victoria's Secret UK goes into administration putting 800 jobs and 25 stores at risk
item.description: The UK arm of lingerie brand Victoria's Secret has slipped into administration, raising fears for more than 800 employees. Now the 25 stores around the country are now under threat of full closure.

item.title: NHS paramedic, 38, surprises her daughters, nine, with the ultimate bear hug
item.description: Sally Boocock, 38, from Skipton, North Yorkshire, separated from her daughters on 9th March so that she could continue working as a frontline emergency medical technician.

item.title: Michel Barnier says there has been NO progress on Brexit talks
item.description: As talks between the two sides remained mired in deadlock today, the UK Government indicated it wanted talks to continue into July to allow an agreement to be reached.

item.title: Care home deaths from any cause rose by 61% during lockdown, data shows
item.description: A report by the Office for National Statistics suggests that undiagnosed Covid-19 is to blame for many of the excess deaths this year, and that elderly people appeared to make up the majority of them.

item.title: Adorable moment mother bird feeds her nine-day-old chicks after building nest on boy's window sill
item.description: A little boy from Puslinch, Ontario, Canada, got a close up view of four robin chicks being fed worms by their mother. The little nine-day-old birds are living in a nest on the boy's windowsill.

item.title: Dramatic moment man angrily smashes a tractor window with a BASEBALL BAT in furious row with driver
item.description: An angry man smashes the window of a tractor on a country road in Mayo, Ireland during an argument in this dramatic video in what is believed to have been a dispute over land.

item.title: Teacher in Ukraine arrested for murder after tying a pillow to one-year-old girl's face
item.description: Irina Sukhanova, 51, has been detained by police in Zaporizhia, south-eastern Ukraine, on suspicion of murder, according to law enforcement officials.

item.title: Father creates huge indoor slide using cardboard boxes on stairs for his children during lockdown
item.description: Parker Wood, from Salem, Utah, created an enormous slide for his children after he was laid off from his job and it has provided hours of entertainment.

item.title: DIY McFly! Back to the Future fanatic takes to skies on a hoverboard using a £340,000 jet pack suit
item.description: Back to the Future fan, Sam Rogers, fulfilled a lifetime ambition as he became the real-life Marty McFly - taking to the skies at a UK-based airfield using a hoverboard and jet suit he created.

item.title: Holiday at home NOT abroad! Culture Secretary urges Britons to have a staycation to save UK tourism
item.description: Tourism chiefs have launched a campaign to call on British holidaymakers to choose vacations in the UK rather than heading abroad for their summer break this year.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Tony Blair urges Government to introduce mass testing programme
item.description: Tony Blair has urged the Government to set up a mass testing programme which would see the bulk of the UK population checked for coronavirus to prevent a second outbreak.

item.title: Met police officer is kicked to the ground during Black Lives Matter protest in London
item.description: A Metropolitan Police officer was kicked to the pavement by a protester in Westminster, London, near the Houses of Parliament. Fellow demonstrators jeered and clapped as the officer fell on the ground.

item.title: High Court rejects Jeremy Bamber bid to release evidence he claims could clear him of murder
item.description: Jeremy Bamber has always protested his innocence and claims his sister, who suffered from schizophrenia, shot her family before turning the gun on herself at White House Farm, Essex.

item.title: Work resumes on British Normandy Memorial commemorating UK troops who died in the 1944 invasion
item.description: Craftsmen were seen carving the words of Winston Churchill's 'We Shall Fight on the Beaches' speech into the stone walls of the British Normandy Memorial in Ver-sur-Mer.

item.title: Greggs will reopen 800 UK branches on June 18
item.description: The popular bakers could not reveal which UK stores will open first but said 150 will be franchises. The shops will have a limited menu with new measures to keep customers and staff safe.

item.title: Last month was warmest May on record says EU climate monitor
item.description: Last month was the warmest May on record with global temperatures 1.13°F (0.63°C) above average, according to the European Union's climate change monitor.

item.title: Bride-to-be drops two dress sizes in five months and drops more pounds during lockdown
item.description: Laura Mee-Bishop, 28, from Derby, weighed just over 14st at Christmas and vowed to slim down to feel confident for her wedding photos, and she's managed to stick to her regime during lockdown.

item.title: What does YOUR sneeze say about your personality?
item.description: British body language expert Robin Kermode has revealed the meaning behind the different types of sneezes, explaining that a 'loud sneezer is often marking his position as an alpha male'.

item.title: Madeleine McCann suspect had a year-long relationship with a British woman
item.description: German paedophile Christian Brueckner, 43, was together with his unidentified English girlfriend from 2004 to 2005 while living near Praia da Luz in Portugal.

item.title: Moment Tommy Robinson 'punches man to the ground' at protest but claims he 'acted in self-defence'
item.description: Tommy Robinson, 37, was detained after police received a report of an assault on a man at Hollywood Retail Park in Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria, shortly after 8.30pm on Thursday.

item.title: The airlines that will let you book NOW with flexibility for late 2020 and early 2021
item.description: In a bid to help UK passengers-in-waiting book flights with peace of mind, flight tips site Head for Points has read the small print so they don't have to.

item.title: Saxons may never have invaded England after the fall of Roman Britain
item.description: However, one expert believes the 5th century of German-speaking Saxon never really happened. Instead, England slowly evolved based on pre-existing Roman culture.

item.title: Couple who moved in together after one date to spend lockdown together reveal they take daily audit
item.description: Speaking to the Guardian , teacher Jack McGarey, 31, and marketer Francesca Elizabeth Williams, 33, from Berkshire revealed their very strict lockdown habits, which sparked a huge reaction on Twitter.

item.title: Thousands of protestors BOO Mayor de Blasio during memorial for George Floyd in Brooklyn
item.description: 'You are not alone,' the large crowd chanted before an emotional Terrence Floyd, wearing a mask and a T-shirt bearing his brother's likeness.

item.title: Thugs brutally attack man and his pregnant wife during violent carjacking outside their home
item.description: CCTV captured the horrifying moment a pregnant woman and her husband were attacked on their driveway by a gang of thugs who then stole their car in King's Norton, Birmingham.

item.title: Foreign-based firms including French fashion giant Chanel share £2.8billion of emergency loans
item.description: The doyen of fashionistas got £600million in Bank of England loans. It is owned by brothers Alain and Gérard Wertheimer, who have personal wealth estimated at £30billion.

item.title: Support for Hong Kong crackdown by China sparks fury
item.description: HSBC and other British firms are facing a growing backlash for supporting Chinese national security laws in Hong Kong that critics have warned will erode the city's freedoms.

item.title: Iran becomes the first country to report a second wave of coronavirus
item.description: Iran reported 3,574 coronavirus infections on Wednesday - a record daily total which comes off the back of a consistent rise in cases which began last month after lockdown was eased.

item.title: Boy's pet lizard tries to catch flies on a game on his phone after mistaking them for real insects
item.description: Luna the lizard, from Kokomo, Indiana, put her bug catching skills to the test when her owner Tyler put his phone inside her tank to keep her entertained.

item.title: First Las Vegas pool party takes place after 78 days of lockdown as hotel casinos open
item.description: Guests at the Flamingo Casino in Las Vegas (pictured) enjoyed a pool party on Thursday for the first time in months after Hotel Casinos opened after 78 days of closure.

item.title: UK government was warned of Britain's 'clear gap in preparedness' for coronavirus
item.description: A report into 'Exercise Iris' in Scotland, which was shared with a UK government advisory group in June last year, also revealed the 'need for substantive progress'.

item.title: Healthy baby is born with coronavirus antibodies after his mother contracted COVID-19
item.description: The boy was born to a woman who is originally from Hubei, where the pandemic started. Doctors said the child's coronavirus antibodies were 'a natural anti-virus ability' passed to him from the mother.

item.title: Superspreaders ARE fuelling the coronavirus pandemic
item.description: Preliminary research from Hong Kong also found 70 per cent of people infected with the virus do not pass it on to anyone else.

item.title: Another top general slams Donald Trump: Former chairman of the joint chiefs Martin Dempsey
item.description: Martin Dempsey, the former Joint Chiefs of Staff chairman, criticized President Trump's threat to use military force and Colin Powell could be next to join the chorus of critics.

item.title: Greta Thunberg calls on EU to condemn US 'police brutality'
item.description: Greta Thunberg, 17, took to Twitter to respond to footage of two police officers shoving a 75-year-old man to the ground, causing him to crack his head on the sidewalk, in Buffalo, New York.

item.title: 'Odds in favour' of finding other young Earth-like planets in young stellar groups
item.description: Experts from Sheffield studied groups of young stars in the Milky way to determine if they were more likely to harbour so-called 'magma ocean planets' - baby Earths.

item.title: 'Interiors therapist' reveals how to use feng shui 'welcome love' into your home
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: In an extract from Welcome Home: How Stuff Makes or Breaks Your Relationship, British expert Suzanne Roynon reveals how to use interior therapy to move forward into a new chapter.

item.title: Half of Britons say they are shunning Chinese products
item.description: Research for MailOnline shows the depth of concern about the UK's reliance on Beijing amid a backlash over its handling of the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Venice flooded by high tides two days after Italy reopened
item.description: Venice was hit by 4ft tides and heavy rain overnight, leaving parts of the lagoon city including iconic St Mark's Square underwater - just two days after Italy reopened its borders to tourists.

item.title: Vicar, 81, who married Romanian toyboy, 27, dies alone
item.description: An 81-year-old former vicar who married his 27-year-old Romanian toyboy lover has died alone in a Bucharest hospital - as his widow reveals he 'cried for two days' but is now ready to enjoy his inheritance.

item.title: Apple supplier suggests iPhone 12 will be delayed at least a month
item.description: A supplier to Apple has revealed that the tech giant's upcoming iPhone will be delayed from its usual September launch, due to the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Pregnant woman gives partner second chance after he fractured her eye socket in savage attack
item.description: Peter Dougal, 32, was arrested after he grabbed Joanne Hough and repeatedly punched her in the face after he became drunk and argumentative during a night out in Lees, Greater Manchester.

item.title: England's coronavirus outbreak shrinks by HALF in a week
item.description: Data from the Office for National Statistics showed that some 39,000 people per week are catching the coronavirus in England - around 5,500 people a day - which is lower than last week.

item.title: Police hunt Madeleine McCann suspect's 'underage Kosovan' ex who lived with him in Praia da Luz
item.description: Officers are hoping to trace the woman, who is believed to have stayed with suspect Christian Brueckner in a house near Praia da Luz, Portugal, prior to the then three-year-old's disappearance.

item.title: AstraZeneca ALREADY manufacturing Covid vaccine in three countries
item.description: AstraZeneca's chief executive, Pascal Soriot, said the firm has started to mass-produce the AZD1222 jab, developed by Oxford University, at factories in India, the UK, Switzerland and Norway.

item.title: Boy, two, is 'in a coma' after being shot in the head
item.description: The shooting happened at 9.45pm yesterday on a road in Harlesden, north west London, police said. Two teenage boys were also shot alongside the baby's mother, 27-year-old Piera Hutton.

item.title: Brazil records 34,000 coronavirus deaths, the world's third highest total behind US and UK
item.description: Brazil reported a new record of 1,473 deaths in 24 hours, bringing its overall toll to 34,021, behind only the US and Britain. The US has had 108,211 deaths while the UK has had 39,987.

item.title: Submerged Italian town could be about to re-emerge from lake
item.description: Fabbriche di Careggine, a former village in Tuscany which now sits beneath the waters of Lake Vagli, could reemerge when the waters are drained to carry out repairs on a dam - with people allowed to visit.

item.title: LinkedIn employees make 'appalling' comments during racial diversity conference
item.description: LinkedIn workers from around the world dialed in to the 'virtual town hall' earlier this week so the company could 'reflect on their own biases, practice allyship, and intentionally drive equitable actions'.

item.title: Masks should be compulsory in shops, restaurants and pubs, says BMA
item.description: Commuters again packed on to the London Underground and were forced to break social distancing rules on the Jubilee Line, which runs through the heart of the capital.

item.title: Full 'Strawberry' Moon coincides with a penumbral lunar eclipse tonight
item.description: While it is called a Strawberry Moon, that doesn't mean it will appear red or pink as the name comes from the fact strawberries are ready to harvest this time of year.

item.title: Mini human livers grown from skin cells are transplanted into rats
item.description: Researchers from the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine say the lab-made organs, grown from skin cells converted into stem cells, survived for four days inside their animal hosts.

item.title: Meghan Markle sounded 'less restrained' and 'like her old self' in George Floyd speech
item.description: Speaking to Vanity Fair today, a friend said the duchess sounded 'less restrained' and more like she did before she joined the royal family in her speech about George Floyd's death.

item.title: People living at high altitude are more resistant to the coronavirus, study claims
item.description: People living at high altitude are less likely to experience the worst effects of coronavirus than those at sea level, a new study suggests.

item.title: British Airways boycotts summit with Priti Patel amid furious row
item.description: Chief Executive of IAG Willie Walsh (pictured) said there had been no consultation with the UK airline industry prior to the rule change and he was reviewing possible action with lawyers.

item.title: Robbers disguised as health inspectors steal £10,000 from South African supermarket
item.description: The armed gang are believed to have made off with 200,000 ZAR, £9,392, from a pension payout point at a supermarket in Pietermaritzburg in KwaZulu-Natal province on Wednesday morning.

item.title: Former IT technician accused of leaving 'fake bomb' says bag containing beer was 'spiritual' message
item.description: Toby Champeney, 57, allegedly left the suspicious package on Downing Street, near Boris Johnson's official residence, on 21 April. He appeared at Westminster Magistrates' Court today.

item.title: NHS contact-tracing app will go live in UK 'by the end of the month'
item.description: The Transport Secretary responded to claims that the app - considered the 'cherry on the cake' of Number 10's flagship Test and Trace scheme - would be 'imperfect' and 'clunky' for several months.

item.title: Neanderthals' low genetic diversity may have caused their extinction, study suggests
item.description: Experts studied variations in the upper neck bone of Neanderthals found in Spain and Croatia - the proliferation of which is associated with low genetic diversity.

item.title: Mother is mad that her ex-husband donates to charity while paying the minimum to support their kids
item.description: A UK-based mother took to Mumsnet to vent her frustration, after finding out her ex-partner makes a monthly financial donation and gives products to a food bank, while paying minimum child support.

item.title: Thrifty mother builds stunning greenhouse she's 'always wanted' for £60
item.description: Elizabeth Bloodworth, from Newbury, built her dream greenhouse using old materials and windows donated by a local company and used an Amazon gift gard to buy extra materials.

item.title: Gucci are charging £610 for pair of furry slippers very similar to Catherine Tate's Nan
item.description: While the comedian's foul-mouthed character no doubt bought the slippers from her high street, a similar pair from Italian fashion house Gucci pair will set shoppers back a whopping £525.

item.title: Councillor slams litter louts for leaving hundreds of 'hippy crack' gas canisters in local park
item.description: The Countryside Alliance has highlighted the scourge of empty laughing gas containers - or 'hippy crack' canisters across the country, as Twitter users share grim scenes in their local parks.

item.title: University of Pittsburgh doctors say coronavirus appears to be declining in potency
item.description: Dr Donald Yealy of the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center explained on Thursday that people seem to be contracting COVID-19 less easily than when the pandemic began earlier this year.

item.title: Kate Garraway breaks down in tears as she discusses husband Derek's battle with coronavirus
item.description: Kate Garraway broke down in tears as she revealed critically-ill husband Derek Draper thanked her for 'saving his life' before he slipped into a coma during his battle with coronavirus.

item.title: Nottinghamshire Police officers rugby tackle fleeing drug dealer after high-speed car chase
item.description: Timothy Glover, 32, was rugby tackled to the ground after a nine-minute police chase during which he jumped red lights and drove the wrong way around bollards in Bulwell, Nottinghamshire.

item.title: Lion whose eye was gouged out in a brutal battle resembles villain in Disney's Lion King
item.description: 'One Eye' was captured on camera in Khwai, Botswana. The lion was left with a gaping wound over his right eye making him bare a striking resemblance to the villain in Disney's Lion King.

item.title: Reckless driver narrowly avoids head-on collision after driving the WRONG WAY around roundabout
item.description: A black Volkswagen forced an oncoming car to stop to avoid a head-on collision after the black car overtook a queue of traffic in Slough before racing the wrong way around a roundabout.

item.title: Drunk ex-nurse drowned in ditch after going for a cigarette while celebrating her 54th birthday
item.description: A former nurse drowned in a drainage ditch behind a marquee at a cider farm near Highbridge, Somerset while celebrating her birthday at a traditional drinking event, an inquest heard.

item.title: Nine News reporter is nearly attacked by crocodile while filming segment in Darwin
item.description: Reporter Zarisha Bradley was filming a segment in Darwin on Thursday when she decided to take a closer look at the beast lurking in the water below.

item.title: Westpac predicts housing affordability will soon be at the best levels since the GFC in 2008
item.description: The weakest immigration pace in more than 100 years, as a result of the COVID-19 border closures, is also set to make mortgages easier to service than usual by Christmas.
item.media:credit: Tertius Pickard for Daily Mail Australia

item.title: Toddler with Down Syndrome can't hide his delight as he meets his newborn baby brother
item.description: This is the adorable moment a boy with Down syndrome meets his baby brother for the first time and can't stop smiling about it - and even gives him a little kiss on his forehead.

item.title: Man is arrested over death of pregnant elephant
item.description: The elephant died after eating food - believed to be pineapple - laced with explosives in India. Today a rubber tapper in his 40s was arrested for handling explosives and assisting others.

item.title: Man, 35, kills three and wounds seven in a stabbing spree at a Chinese supermarket
item.description: The suspected attacker, a 35-year-old man, was arrested shortly after the incident late Thursday in Putian city of Fujian province, said police without specifying the kind of weapon used.

item.title: Man who was bullied at school and called 'pizza face' gets paid to work with top skincare brands
item.description: Instagrammer Scott McGlynn, 33, from Wales, has told how he was bullied and called 'pizza face' and 'spotty boy' at school - but now gets paid to work with top skincare brands.

item.title: Mother shares picture of her daughter 'taking a knee'
item.description: Helen Leathem, from London, posted a picture of her daughter kneeling on their doorstep while holding a poster with 'privileged' in rainbow letters and an arrow pointing upwards.

item.title: The only man who could solve the issue of Karl Lagerfeld's inheritance has disappeared
item.description: Voici magazine reported that Lucien Frydlender, 87, fro Paris, knows the exact state of the late designer's assets. But he is uncontactable, while seven heirs wrangle over the designer's will.

item.title: Variety Editor-in-Chief Claudia Eller takes a two-month leave
item.description: Variety Editor-in-Chief Claudia Eller announced she would be taking an administrative leave after getting into a Twitter fight with journalist Piya Sinha-Roy over diversity in its newsroom

item.title: Pence invites Trump activist who called George Floyd 'horrible' to meeting
item.description: Black conservative activist Candace Owens was included in Vice President Mike Pence's roundtable on race relations Thursday, despite calling George Floyd a 'horrible human being.'

item.title: Netflix LGBTQ strategy executive quits after 'eyebrow raising' interview
item.description: Fran Tirado, 29, took to Twitter on May 21 to announce he had left the streaming service after 10 months and was on the lookout for a new job.

item.title: Leigh Francis issues an emotional apology for playing black people on his show Bo' Selecta!
item.description: The comedian, 47, who is best known as Keith Lemon, said he was 'deeply sorry for any upset' he caused for dressing up as black celebrities on his noughties show Bo' Selecta!.

item.title: Gabrielle Union's husband Dwyane Wade says family was UNDER SURVEILLANCE amid her rift with NBC
item.description: In her complaint. Union, 47, said network entertainment chair Paul Telegdy tried to stop her 'from telling the truth about racist actions that took place' on the network variety program.

item.title: Medical student reveals the truth about chewing gum and whether it stays in your stomach
item.description: A medical student has revealed the truth about chewing gum, and whether it really does your body any harm if you swallow it. Justin, 23, from Canada, tackled the myths surrounding chewing gum.

item.title: CHRISTOPHER STEVENS: Memo to revellers - it's not just Covid that's a threat to the NHS
item.description: CHRISTOPHER STEVENS: Protect the NHS. That's the three words that sum up all of Britain's determination to keep hospitals functioning throughout the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Kylie Jenner tops Forbes Magazine's highest-paid celebrities list despite not being a billionaire
item.description: According to Forbes, Kylie, 22, earned $590 million over the past year, most of which was thanks to beauty giant Coty buying a 51 percent stake of Kylie Cosmetics last January.

item.title: Former Home Secretary DAVID BLUNKETT: Why I am so uneasy about police 'taking the knee'
item.description: DAVID BLUNKETT: Why did I feel so uneasy when I heard reports of British police officers adopting a powerful anti-racist gesture and 'taking the knee' at demonstrations in London?

item.title: Cannibals use corpses as altars and drink from human skulls
item.description: The Aghori sect, known for practising post-mortem rituals and cannibalism, live close to crematory grounds in northern India where they devote their lives to meditation and prayer.

item.title: Australian pet owner returns home to find his dog has ripped his new £2,800 sofa to shreds
item.description: Jaccob Mckay, 26, was shocked to come home and see sofa stuffing all over his living room in Olinda near Melbourne, Australia. He believes 10-month-old Cypress was protesting being left alone.
